repnme.cdata!:
Somalia - Recurrent Cost and Reform
            Financing Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Recurrent Cost and
            Reform Financing Project for Somalia were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was significant, Bank performance was satisfactory,
            and Grantee performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: use of country systems (UCS) was a
            bold step which ensured fiduciary assurance as well as
            sustained client capacity building. Payment systems need to
            migrate to direct transfer of salaries to accounts of civil
            servants in commercial bank accounts. In context of travel
            restrictions, supervision needs to be augmented by using a
            supervisory agent model. The implementation of a financial
            management information system is a big leap in context of
            improving internal controls on this and other projects.
            Drawing lessons from the engagement with the monitoring
            agent (MA) for the Afghanistan Reconstruction Trust Fund
            (ARTF); this is based on relatively clear and simple terms
            of reference (ToR) which requires a confirmation on the
            veracity of the recurrent costs on a monthly basis and the
            more systemic issues to be addressed in depth in a quarterly report.

24883951.theme: Public expenditure, financial management and procurement

repnme.cdata!:
Somalia - Recurrent Costs and Reform
            Financing Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Recurrent Costs and Reform Financing
            Project for Somalia seeks to make the following changes to
            the project: a) An extension of the closing date by two
            months to enable financing of eligible civil service
            salaries in non-security sectors in Mogadishu; and salaries
            and allowances for Subject Matter Experts for January and
            February 2015. Additionally, it will facilitate the
            extension of contracts of consultants supporting the
            External Affairs Fiduciary Section (EAFS) for project
            implementation to April 2015. b) A reallocation from
            component three and two to component one to finance the
            payments of civil service salaries in non-security sectors
            and payment of fees and allowances to Subject Matter Experts
            who are supporting the core government functions for the
            months of January to March. c) A revision of the Results
            Framework based on the findings of the mid-term review to be
            able to better measure the PDO indicators, baselines,
            progress data and targets for all indicators and adjust
            and/or add any indicators to show all the results that the
            project has been achieved. There are no changes in the PDO.
